Tell that to my sword blade's that are pre-showa. 
  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: nihontochicken<mailto:rick@...> 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com<mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com> 
  Sent: Sunday, July 23, 2006 11:21 AM
  Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Antique katana blade - showa stamp


  Yes, many ancestral blades were remounted in gunto koshirae and
  carried off to the Pacific War. But they were not stamped with the
  Showa cherry blossom. A Showa stamp, also the nearly as common Seki
  stamp, indicates the blade is not completely traditionally made. In
  some better examples that look very traditional, displaying both hada
  and water tempered hamon, the stamp indicates it was made with western
  style steel instead of the traditional tamahagane.

  NC

  --- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com<mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>, "mark sala" <franzkafka19@...> wrote:
  >
  > Yes this is true. Old mounts removed and new military mounts as
  replacements. Reason for this is to make the sword SHOWA. I have
  several, well more than several. Mark Happy collecting.
  > ----- Original Message -----

  > that the presence of a Showa stamp means the blade is circa WWII.

  > Showa stamp for use during WWII. What is the truth?
